title: 2014 Chicago Bears season
text:
The <a href="Chicago%20Bears">Chicago Bears</a> <a href="List%20of%20Chicago%20Bears%20seasons">season</a> was the franchise's 95th season in the <a href="National%20Football%20League">National Football League</a>, as well as the second under <a href="List%20of%20Chicago%20Bears%20head%20coaches">head coach</a> <a href="Marc%20Trestman">Marc Trestman</a>. The Bears failed to qualify for the playoffs after being eliminated from contention in week fourteen, their fourth consecutive season without making the postseason.
The Bears entered 2014 with hopes of improving their 8–8 record in 2013. After losing the season opener to the <a href="2014%20Buffalo%20Bills%20season">Buffalo Bills</a>, the Bears won their next two games. However, this would be the only week of 2014 that the Bears had a winning record, as they fell to 3–5 upon reaching the bye week. The Bears lost three of those games by more than one touchdown, and allowed more than 50 points in consecutive games against the <a href="2014%20New%20England%20Patriots%20season">New England Patriots</a> and <a href="2014%20Green%20Bay%20Packers%20season">Green Bay Packers</a>. The Bears won two straight games after the loss to the Packers, but ended the season with five consecutive losses, all but two (in the second games against the <a href="2014%20Detroit%20Lions%20season">Detroit Lions</a> and <a href="2014%20Minnesota%20Vikings%20season">Minnesota Vikings</a>) by more than two scores. The Bears ended the season 5–11, their first losing season since <a href="2009%20Chicago%20Bears%20season">2009</a> and first season with more than ten losses since <a href="2004%20Chicago%20Bears%20season">2004</a>.
General manager <a href="Phil%20Emery%20%28American%20football%29">Phil Emery</a> was fired on December 29, and Trestman was fired later in the day.
Offseason.
Organizational changes.
After the defense set franchise worsts in points (478), total yards (6,313) and rushing yards (2,583) allowed, defensive line coach <a href="Mike%20Phair">Mike Phair</a> and linebackers coach <a href="Tim%20Tibesar">Tim Tibesar</a> were fired by the team on January 12. Head coach <a href="Marc%20Trestman">Marc Trestman</a> stated, "We need to improve in all areas defensively and that will be a focal point for us this offseason. The process starts with me as the head coach. Our search for a defensive line and linebackers coach has begun and we will be looking for the best candidates whose experience can bring the most out of our veteran and young players in both areas." On January 22, <a href="Houston%20Texans">Houston Texans</a> linebacker coach <a href="Reggie%20Herring">Reggie Herring</a> was hired to take Tibesar's place, while former <a href="Dallas%20Cowboys">Dallas Cowboys</a> defensive coordinator and <a href="Connecticut%20Huskies%20football">Connecticut Huskies</a> head coach <a href="Paul%20Pasqualoni">Paul Pasqualoni</a> became the defensive line coach. On January 25, assistant defensive line coach <a href="Michael%20Sinclair%20%28American%20football%29">Michael Sinclair</a> was replaced by <a href="Louisville%20Cardinals%20football">Louisville</a> defensive line coach <a href="Clint%20Hurtt">Clint Hurtt</a>. On February 12, assistant offensive line coach <a href="Pat%20Meyer">Pat Meyer</a> was promoted to offensive line, while martial artist <a href="Joe%20Kim">Joe Kim</a> was hired as assistant strength/skill development coach.
On February 7, assistant head athletic trainer/director of rehabilitation <a href="Bobby%20Slater">Bobby Slater</a> joined the <a href="Tampa%20Bay%20Buccaneers">Tampa Bay Buccaneers</a> after 15 years of service with the Bears.
Roster changes.
The Bears enter the offseason with 27 players set to become free agents, 17 of whom are on defense, with safety <a href="Anthony%20Walters%20%28American%20football%29">Anthony Walters</a> being a <a href="restricted%20free%20agent">restricted free agent</a>, while guard <a href="Taylor%20Boggs">Taylor Boggs</a> and defensive lineman <a href="Cheta%20Ozougwu">Cheta Ozougwu</a> are exclusive rights free agents. <a href="CBS%20Sports">CBS Sports</a> writer Joel Corry projected the Bears' salary cap to be <a href="USD">$</a>41,632,799, with an adjusted cap of $128,013,800, which ranked fourth in the league, behind the <a href="Cleveland%20Browns">Cleveland Browns</a>, <a href="Jacksonville%20Jaguars">Jacksonville Jaguars</a> and <a href="Oakland%20Raiders">Oakland Raiders</a>. By February 22, the Bears' salary cap was approximately $2.7 million.
Acquisitions.
The first acquisition of 2014 occurred on February 17, when defensive end <a href="Austen%20Lane">Austen Lane</a> was signed. The following day, cornerback Derricus Purdy was signed. On March 6, the Bears signed defensive end <a href="Trevor%20Scott">Trevor Scott</a>. On March 11, the first day of free agency, the Bears signed defensive lineman <a href="Lamarr%20Houston">Lamarr Houston</a>, safety <a href="Ryan%20Mundy">Ryan Mundy</a> and linebacker <a href="Jordan%20Senn">Jordan Senn</a>. On March 12, the Bears signed cornerback <a href="M.%20D.%20Jennings">M. D. Jennings</a>. On March 13, defensive end and wide receiver <a href="Willie%20Young%20%28defensive%20end%29">Willie Young</a> and <a href="Domenik%20Hixon">Domenik Hixon</a>, respectively, were signed. Five days later, former Bears defensive end <a href="Israel%20Idonije">Israel Idonije</a> and safety <a href="Danny%20McCray">Danny McCray</a> were signed. On March 26, the Bears signed <a href="Minnesota%20Vikings">Minnesota Vikings</a> star defensive end <a href="Jared%20Allen">Jared Allen</a>. On April 6, center <a href="Brian%20de%20la%20Puente">Brian de la Puente</a> was signed. The following day, Chicago signed former <a href="Canadian%20Football%20League">Canadian Football League</a> long snapper <a href="Chad%20Rempel">Chad Rempel</a>. <a href="Washington%20Redskins">Washington Redskins</a> receiver <a href="Josh%20Bellamy">Josh Bellamy</a> was acquired via waivers by the Bears, and tight end <a href="Matt%20Mulligan">Matt Mulligan</a> was signed, both on April 8. Thirteen days later, wide receiver <a href="Josh%20Morgan">Josh Morgan</a> was signed, followed by running back <a href="Shaun%20Draughn">Shaun Draughn</a> three days after. On June 3, receivers <a href="Armanti%20Edwards">Armanti Edwards</a> and <a href="Micheal%20Spurlock">Micheal Spurlock</a> were signed, and two weeks later, Chicago signed quarterback <a href="Jimmy%20Clausen">Jimmy Clausen</a>. On June 19, defensive lineman <a href="Jamil%20Merrell">Jamil Merrell</a> and linebacker <a href="Conor%20O%27Neill">Conor O'Neill</a>, both being undrafted free agents, were signed. Four days later, five-time <a href="Pro%20Bowl">Pro Bowl</a> safety <a href="Adrian%20Wilson%20%28American%20football%29">Adrian Wilson</a> and tight end <a href="Jeron%20Mastrud">Jeron Mastrud</a> were acquired, and were the final acquisitions by the Bears prior to Training Camp.
Departures.
On March 5, the first departure of the year was punter <a href="Adam%20Podlesh">Adam Podlesh</a>. Five days later, running back <a href="Michael%20Bush">Michael Bush</a> was waived. Eleven days after signing, tight end <a href="Dante%20Rosario">Dante Rosario</a> was released on March 10. On March 11, defensive end <a href="Julius%20Peppers">Julius Peppers</a> was released after the Bears were unable to trade him. He later signed a deal with the <a href="Green%20Bay%20Packers">Green Bay Packers</a>. On March 18, receiver <a href="Earl%20Bennett">Earl Bennett</a> was waived after refusing to have his salary reduced. On April 15, the Bears released defensive end <a href="Cheta%20Ozougwu">Cheta Ozougwu</a>. On June 3, linebacker <a href="Tana%20Patrick">Tana Patrick</a> was waived. On June 19, quarterback <a href="Jerrod%20Johnson">Jerrod Johnson</a>, tight end <a href="Fendi%20Onobun">Fendi Onobun</a>, defensive lineman <a href="Israel%20Idonije">Israel Idonije</a> and safety <a href="Sean%20Cattouse">Sean Cattouse</a> were waived.
On March 12, unrestricted free agent quarterback <a href="Josh%20McCown">Josh McCown</a> signed a deal with the <a href="Tampa%20Bay%20Buccaneers">Tampa Bay Buccaneers</a>. Six days later, defensive end <a href="Henry%20Melton">Henry Melton</a> joined the <a href="Dallas%20Cowboys">Dallas Cowboys</a>. On March 20, special teamer <a href="Devin%20Hester">Devin Hester</a> and defensive lineman <a href="Corey%20Wootton">Corey Wootton</a> were signed by the <a href="Atlanta%20Falcons">Atlanta Falcons</a> and Vikings, respectively. Cornerback <a href="Zack%20Bowman">Zack Bowman</a> joined the <a href="New%20York%20Giants">New York Giants</a> on March 31. On April 4, safety <a href="Major%20Wright">Major Wright</a> was signed by Tampa Bay. In May, <a href="Anthony%20Walters%20%28American%20football%29">Anthony Walters</a> signed with the <a href="Arizona%20Cardinals">Arizona Cardinals</a> and Ozougwu joined the <a href="New%20Orleans%20Saints">New Orleans Saints</a> on May 14 and 18, respectively. From June 3–4, linebacker <a href="Blake%20Costanzo">Blake Costanzo</a> was signed by the <a href="San%20Francisco%2049ers">San Francisco 49ers</a>, followed by <a href="James%20Anderson%20%28American%20football%29">James Anderson</a> with the <a href="New%20England%20Patriots">New England Patriots</a>. On June 20, long snapper <a href="Patrick%20Mannelly">Patrick Mannelly</a> retired after 16 seasons in the NFL, all with the Bears.
2014 draft class.
The Bears did not receive any <a href="NFL%20Draft%23Compensatory%20picks">compensatory picks</a> for the draft. <a href="Profootballtalk.com">Profootballtalk.com</a>'s Michael David Smith wrote Chicago needed to draft players at four positions for the first round: defensive back, with first-round possibilities including <a href="Ha%20Ha%20Clinton-Dix">Ha Ha Clinton-Dix</a> and <a href="Justin%20Gilbert">Justin Gilbert</a>; linebacker, such as <a href="C.%20J.%20Mosley%20%28linebacker%29">C. J. Mosley</a> and <a href="Ryan%20Shazier">Ryan Shazier</a>; defensive tackle, like <a href="Aaron%20Donald">Aaron Donald</a>. Additionally, Smith wrote the Bears could target a running back or quarterback with mid- to late-round draft picks, such as <a href="De%27Anthony%20Thomas">De'Anthony Thomas</a> and <a href="James%20White%20%28running%20back%29">James White</a>, and <a href="Tom%20Savage%20%28American%20football%29">Tom Savage</a>, respectively.
With the 14th pick in the draft, the Bears selected <a href="Virginia%20Tech%20Hokies%20football">Virginia Tech</a> cornerback <a href="Kyle%20Fuller">Kyle Fuller</a>, who recorded 173 tackles, 4.5 sacks, six interceptions and 21 deflections during his college career. In round two, with the 51st pick, <a href="LSU%20Tigers%20football">LSU</a> defensive lineman <a href="Ego%20Ferguson">Ego Ferguson</a> was drafted; Ferguson had started only one full season in 2013, recording a sack, but had his season end due to an injury, which had prevented him from participating in the <a href="NFL%20Scouting%20Combine">NFL Scouting Combine</a>. In the following round, Chicago drafted defensive tackle <a href="Will%20Sutton">Will Sutton</a> of <a href="Arizona%20State%20Sun%20Devils%20football">Arizona State</a> with the 82nd pick; Sutton recorded 20.5 sacks in his college career, while leading the <a href="Pac-12%20Conference">Pac-12 Conference</a> with 10.5 sacks and 20 tackles for loss in 2012. The Bears held two fourth-rounders: the 117 and 131, the latter being acquired after a trade with the <a href="Denver%20Broncos">Denver Broncos</a>. The former was used on <a href="Arizona%20Wildcats%20football">Arizona</a> running back <a href="Ka%27Deem%20Carey">Ka'Deem Carey</a>, the school's career-leading rusher, and was considered as the best running back available by numerous experts. The 131st pick was used on <a href="Minnesota%20Golden%20Gophers%20football">Minnesota</a> safety <a href="Brock%20Vereen">Brock Vereen</a>. As a result of the trade with Denver, the Bears did not have a fifth-rounder. In the sixth round, with the 183rd pick, <a href="San%20Jose%20State%20Spartans%20football">San Jose State</a> quarterback <a href="David%20Fales">David Fales</a> was drafted, who holds every passing record in school history. The next round, with the 191st pick, <a href="Miami%20Hurricanes%20football">Miami</a> punter <a href="Pat%20O%27Donnell">Pat O'Donnell</a> was drafted; O'Donnell led the <a href="Atlantic%20Coast%20Conference">Atlantic Coast Conference</a> and ranked second in the nation in punting average with 47.1 yards. The Bears' final pick, the 191st pick in the seventh round, was <a href="Boise%20State%20Broncos%20football">Boise State</a> offensive lineman <a href="Charles%20Leno%20Jr.">Charles Leno Jr.</a>, who started 36 consecutive games since 2011.
Analysts gave above average grades for the draft class. <a href="James%20Neveau">James Neveau</a> of <a href="WMAQ-TV">WMAQ-TV</a> graded the offensive selections as an "A", considering Carey as the "best value pick" by the Bears. On defense and special teams, Neveau gave the picks a "B+", praising Sutton's selection, but doubted the decision to take Ferguson in the second round. NFL.com's <a href="Bucky%20Brooks">Bucky Brooks</a> wrote Carey was the biggest steal of the draft among NFC North draft picks, ultimately giving the Bears' class a "B". <a href="Foxsports.com">Foxsports.com</a>, who gave the Bears a "B", praised Carey, while stating that despite playing well in 2012, Sutton had been too heavy in 2013, and must be "at the right playing weight in 2014 to make a difference in the big leagues". Chris Burke and Doug Farrar of "<a href="Sports%20Illustrated">Sports Illustrated</a>" considered the Sutton and Carey selections as "a win for the team's Southwest area scout"; the two gave the class an "A-". <a href="ESPN">ESPN</a> analyst <a href="Mel%20Kiper%20Jr.">Mel Kiper Jr.</a> awarded the class a "B", believing the team performed well in focusing on team needs, and stating he is fine with Fuller's selection, as Gilbert is not "superior to Fuller", though Clinton-Dix would've been a good selection; <a href="Todd%20McShay">Todd McShay</a>, another ESPN analyst, considered Vereen as the best NFC North selection.
All eight rookies were signed to four-year deals. Two days after the draft, on May 12, Vereen and Fales were signed. Ferguson, Carey, Fales, O'Donnell, and Leno were signed the following day, followed by Fuller the next day, and concluded with Sutton on May 15. The Bears were the first team to sign a draftee in 2014, and the first to complete signing their class.
After the draft, the Bears signed nine undrafted free agents: quarterback <a href="Jordan%20Lynch">Jordan Lynch</a> of <a href="Northern%20Illinois%20Huskies%20football">Northern Illinois</a>, who was listed as a running back; defensive tackles <a href="Brandon%20Dunn">Brandon Dunn</a> (<a href="Louisville%20Cardinals%20football">Louisville</a>) and <a href="Lee%20Pegues">Lee Pegues</a> (<a href="East%20Carolina%20Pirates%20football">East Carolina</a>); guards <a href="Ryan%20Groy">Ryan Groy</a> (<a href="Wisconsin%20Badgers%20football">Wisconsin</a>) and <a href="James%20Dunbar%20%28American%20football%29">James Dunbar</a> (<a href="TCU%20Horned%20Frogs%20football">TCU</a>); tackle <a href="Cody%20Booth">Cody Booth</a> (<a href="Temple%20Owls%20football">Temple</a>); and linebackers <a href="Tana%20Patrick">Tana Patrick</a> (<a href="Alabama%20Crimson%20Tide%20football">Alabama</a>), <a href="Christian%20Jones%20%28American%20football%29">Christian Jones</a> (<a href="Florida%20State%20Seminoles%20football">Florida State</a>) and <a href="Devekeyan%20Lattimore">Devekeyan Lattimore</a> (<a href="USF%20Bulls%20football">USF</a>).
Offseason activities.
The Bears began their offseason program on April 22, with a mandatory minicamp ending the program from June 17–19.
Rookie minicamp.
The Bears began rookie minicamp on May 16, which lasted for three days, in the <a href="Walter%20Payton%20Center">Walter Payton Center</a>. Asides from the eight drafted rookies, the undrafted rookies signed after the draft, and 2013 rookies, 38 players were present for tryouts, including four Illinois-born players. At the end of the camp, punter <a href="Drew%20Butler">Drew Butler</a> was waived, while tryout players <a href="Senorise%20Perry">Senorise Perry</a>, a running back from <a href="Louisville%20Cardinals%20football">Louisville</a>, and <a href="North%20Texas%20Mean%20Green%20football">North Texas</a> safety <a href="Marcus%20Trice">Marcus Trice</a> were signed.
Training Camp.
Training Camp at <a href="Olivet%20Nazarene%20University">Olivet Nazarene University</a> in <a href="Bourbonnais%2C%20Illinois">Bourbonnais, Illinois</a> began on July 24, with the first practice the following day. The first two practices were held without pads; additional practices were held from July 27–28, and from July 30–August 1.
<a href="Kyle%20Long">Kyle Long</a> missed the seven practices due to a viral infection. <a href="Chris%20Conte">Chris Conte</a> and <a href="Craig%20Steltz">Craig Steltz</a> did not participate on the first day due to a shoulder and groin injury, respectively; both were later placed on the active physically-unable-to-perform (PUP) list. The second day's practice featured <a href="Tim%20Jennings">Tim Jennings</a> and Willie Young having quadriceps injuries, the latter participating, but leaving prior to the end. The next day, Jennings and Young returned, but the former left after the first play. <a href="Terrence%20Toliver">Terrence Toliver</a> didn't play due to a toe injury. <a href="Alshon%20Jeffery">Alshon Jeffery</a>, Toliver, Conte, and Steltz skipped July 28 practice, Jeffery due to a sore foot. After a day off on July 29, Jeffery returned, while Jennings participated in individual drills. During the day, <a href="Eben%20Britton">Eben Britton</a> suffered a torn hamstring during a one-on-one drill with <a href="Jeremiah%20Ratliff">Jeremiah Ratliff</a>. Despite being cleared to return, Long did not practice until Family Fest. <a href="Roberto%20Garza">Roberto Garza</a> skipped the August 1 practice for "personal reasons".
The annual Family Fest at Soldier Field was held on August 2 in front of 27,000 spectators. Long made his return at the event, along with Garza, while <a href="Shaun%20Draughn">Shaun Draughn</a> was not present for personal issues. Jared Allen and Ratliff were excused. Later practices were held in Bourbonnais from August 4–6, with the first preseason game on the following day. On August 4, Jeffery, Britton, Conte, Steltz, and Draughn did not practice, while <a href="Lance%20Briggs">Lance Briggs</a> bruised a knee; the first major injury of Training Camp was <a href="Marquess%20Wilson">Marquess Wilson</a>'s broken clavicle. During the session, a fight between <a href="Martellus%20Bennett">Martellus Bennett</a> and <a href="Kyle%20Fuller">Kyle Fuller</a> occurred: while attempting to force Bennett to fumble, Fuller grabbed Bennett's shoulder pad, pulling him down. In retaliation, Bennett body-slammed Fuller, causing Lamarr Houston, <a href="Matt%20Forte">Matt Forte</a> and <a href="Zach%20Miller%20%28tight%20end%2C%20born%201984%29">Zach Miller</a>, along with offensive coordinator <a href="Aaron%20Kromer">Aaron Kromer</a> to intervene. Head coach <a href="Marc%20Trestman">Marc Trestman</a> would end the practice earlier than scheduled. The next day, Bennett was indefinitely suspended by the team. August 5's practice featured Britton, Briggs, Allen, and Draughn being absent, while <a href="Jordan%20Mills">Jordan Mills</a> injured his foot prior to the end of the workout. On August 6, Long, <a href="Isaiah%20Frey">Isaiah Frey</a>, Mills, Britton, Jennings, Steltz, Conte, and Allen did not practice. The final practices would be held from August 10 to 12. Bennett was reinstated and practiced on August 10, while Steltz and Conte returned to practice. However, Mills, Britton, <a href="Chris%20Williams%20%28wide%20receiver%29">Chris Williams</a>, Frey, and Brian de la Puente did not practice. The five, Wilson, and Briggs did not work out the next day, with Briggs being given a day off. August 12's practice had Williams, Britton, Mills, Wilson, Frey, Dante Rosario, Tillman, and Ratliff out.
On July 25, offensive lineman <a href="Dylan%20Gandy">Dylan Gandy</a> was signed, while Jamil Merrell was waived. James Dunbar was released two days later. On July 29, receiver <a href="Dale%20Moss">Dale Moss</a> was signed. Two days later, Toliver was released via an injury settlement, while offensive linemen <a href="Graham%20Pocic">Graham Pocic</a> and <a href="Dennis%20Roland">Dennis Roland</a> were signed. On August 6, <a href="Greg%20Herd">Greg Herd</a> was signed, while Conor O'Neil was released.
Preseason.
Schedule.
The Bears' preseason opponents were announced on April 9, 2014. The Bears began the preseason at home against the <a href="Philadelphia%20Eagles">Philadelphia Eagles</a>, who had hampered the Bears' playoff chances in 2013 after a 54–11 win. The next two games would be away games against the <a href="Jacksonville%20Jaguars">Jacksonville Jaguars</a> on <a href="ESPN">ESPN</a>, followed by the <a href="Super%20Bowl%20XLVIII">defending</a> <a href="Super%20Bowl">Super Bowl</a> champion <a href="Seattle%20Seahawks">Seattle Seahawks</a>. The Bears would end the preseason against <a href="Chicago%20Bears%23Other%20rivals">frequent opponent</a> <a href="Cleveland%20Browns">Cleveland Browns</a>, marking the eleventh consecutive preseason closer between the two teams.
Game summaries.
In the preseason opener against the Eagles, <a href="Craig%20Steltz">Craig Steltz</a>, <a href="Tim%20Jennings">Tim Jennings</a>, <a href="Isaiah%20Frey">Isaiah Frey</a>, <a href="Chris%20Conte">Chris Conte</a>, <a href="Eben%20Britton">Eben Britton</a>, <a href="Jordan%20Mills">Jordan Mills</a>, <a href="Jared%20Allen">Jared Allen</a>, <a href="Kyle%20Long">Kyle Long</a>, and <a href="Martellus%20Bennett">Martellus Bennett</a> did not participate. On the Eagles' first possession, <a href="Nick%20Foles">Nick Foles</a> was pressured by <a href="Willie%20Young%20%28defensive%20end%29">Willie Young</a> and <a href="Lamarr%20Houston">Lamarr Houston</a> into having a pass intercepted by <a href="Ryan%20Mundy">Ryan Mundy</a>. However, <a href="Robbie%20Gould">Robbie Gould</a>'s 41-yard field goal was blocked by <a href="Damion%20Square">Damion Square</a>. On Chicago's next drive, the offense traveled 69 yards, culminating in <a href="Jay%20Cutler">Jay Cutler</a>'s ten-yard touchdown pass to <a href="Zach%20Miller%20%28tight%20end%2C%20born%201984%29">Zach Miller</a>. Foles, who had thrown only two interceptions in 2012, would be intercepted again after his pass intended for <a href="Zach%20Ertz">Zach Ertz</a> was intercepted by <a href="Sherrick%20McManis">Sherrick McManis</a>. In the second quarter, <a href="Matthew%20Tucker">Matthew Tucker</a>'s 4-yard and 1-yard touchdown runs gave the Eagles the 14–7 lead. <a href="Jordan%20Palmer">Jordan Palmer</a> threw a 12-yard touchdown pass to Miller, but <a href="Josh%20Huff">Josh Huff</a> would return the following kickoff 102 yards for a touchdown to end the first half with the Eagles leading 21–14. In the third quarter, <a href="Khaseem%20Greene">Khaseem Greene</a> forced Tucker to fumble, with the Bears scoring on Gould's 26-yard field goal. <a href="Matt%20Barkley">Matt Barkley</a> then threw a 14-yard touchdown pass to <a href="David%20Fluellen">David Fluellen</a> to increase the lead to 28–17, but the margin would be shortened with <a href="Jimmy%20Clausen">Jimmy Clausen</a>'s 73-yard touchdown pass to <a href="Chris%20Williams%20%28wide%20receiver%29">Chris Williams</a>; the Bears would fail to score on the two-point conversion after Clausen's pass was batted. Chicago would claim the lead after Clausen's 22-yard touchdown pass to <a href="Micheal%20Spurlock">Micheal Spurlock</a>, followed by <a href="Dante%20Rosario">Dante Rosario</a> scoring on the two-point conversion to make the score 31–28. In the fourth quarter, <a href="David%20Fales">David Fales</a> threw a 41-yard pass to <a href="Josh%20Bellamy">Josh Bellamy</a>, but the drive ended after his pass for Bellamy was intercepted by <a href="Jaylen%20Watkins">Jaylen Watkins</a>. The Bears would begin rushing to spend time, going 73 yards before Gould kicked a 25-yard field goal, the final points of the game.
Against Jacksonville, <a href="Marquess%20Wilson">Marquess Wilson</a>, Steltz, <a href="Isaiah%20Frey">Isaiah Frey</a>, Conte, Britton, <a href="Brian%20de%20la%20Puente">Brian de la Puente</a>, Mills, Williams, Rosario and Young were scratched from the game-day roster. The Jaguars scored first, off <a href="Josh%20Scobee">Josh Scobee</a>'s two field goals of 49 and 25 yards. On the latter play's ensuing kickoff, <a href="Eric%20Weems">Eric Weems</a> fumbled, and the ball was recovered by <a href="Will%20Blackmon">Will Blackmon</a>; Jacksonville would capitalize on the recovery, with <a href="Chad%20Henne">Chad Henne</a>'s six-yard touchdown pass to <a href="Marqise%20Lee">Marqise Lee</a>. In the second quarter, the Bears scored their first points of the game with Cutler's four-yard touchdown pass to <a href="Brandon%20Marshall">Brandon Marshall</a>. Scobee would kick a 43-yard field goal, the last score of the half. The Bears' first drive of the second half ended with Clausen being intercepted by <a href="Josh%20Evans%20%28defensive%20back%29">Josh Evans</a>. Jacksonville would convert the takeaway into <a href="Kasey%20Redfern">Kasey Redfern</a>'s 29-yard field goal, the lone score of the third quarter. On Chicago's first drive of the fourth quarter, <a href="Ka%27Deem%20Carey">Ka'Deem Carey</a> scored on a one-yard run. With 50 seconds left in the game, <a href="Senorise%20Perry">Senorise Perry</a> scored on a five-yard run, but failed the two-point conversion, making the score 20–19. With 27 seconds remaining, <a href="C.%20J.%20Wilson%20%28cornerback%29">C. J. Wilson</a> intercepted <a href="Stephen%20Morris%20%28American%20football%29">Stephen Morris</a> to clinch the victory.
Wilson, <a href="Kyle%20Fuller">Kyle Fuller</a>, Frey, Britton, de la Puente, Mills, Allen, and Williams were inactive in Seattle. The Seahawks scored touchdowns on their first four drives: <a href="Marshawn%20Lynch">Marshawn Lynch</a> and <a href="Russell%20Wilson">Russell Wilson</a>'s seven-yard touchdown runs in the first quarter and Wilson's touchdown passes to <a href="Jermaine%20Kearse">Jermaine Kearse</a> and <a href="Christine%20Michael">Christine Michael</a> of seven- and 29 yards, respectively, in the second quarter. For the Bears' four first quarter drives, three ended in punts; on the team's final possession of the second quarter, Cutler's 23-yard touchdown pass to Bennett was nullified when Bennett was downed at the one-yard line. Cutler would throw a two-yard touchdown pass to Rosario, but a pass interference call on Marshall overturned the play; Cutler would be intercepted by <a href="Jeremy%20Lane%20%28American%20football%29">Jeremy Lane</a>; the Seahawks would convert the turnover into a <a href="Steven%20Hauschka">Steven Hauschka</a> 59-yard field goal to give the Seahawks a 31–0 lead. On Seattle's first drive of the second half, they failed to score for the first time of the game when Hauschka's 53-yard field goal hit the left upright; Gould would also miss a field goal, missing a 43-yarder wide right. Hauschka would record the only score of the third quarter, with a 38-yard field goal. In the final quarter, the Bears would reach the Seahawks' red zone, where Gould scored on a 30-yard kick. On Seattle's ensuing play, <a href="Terrelle%20Pryor">Terrelle Pryor</a> was intercepted by C. J. Wilson, leading to a Gould 38-yard field goal to make the final score 34–6.
Visiting the Browns, the Bears sat their starters, having only 35 of 75 players participating, while the Browns kept their starters in the game. After the Bears scored on the opening drive off Gould's 39-yard field goal, the Browns took the lead off <a href="Ben%20Tate">Ben Tate</a>'s one-yard touchdown run; Gould would eventually miss a 52-yarder wide right. On Cleveland's next drive, <a href="Terrance%20West">Terrance West</a> fumbled, allowing <a href="M.%20D.%20Jennings">M. D. Jennings</a> to recover. Early in the second quarter, Fales threw a pass to <a href="Santonio%20Holmes">Santonio Holmes</a>, who escaped <a href="Justin%20Gilbert">Justin Gilbert</a> to score on the 32-yard play. The Bears scored again via Gould's 23-yard field goal, but the Browns took the 14–13 lead with <a href="Johnny%20Manziel">Johnny Manziel</a>'s one-yard touchdown pass to <a href="Jim%20Dray">Jim Dray</a>. The Browns extended the lead on their final drive with <a href="Billy%20Cundiff">Billy Cundiff</a>'s 22-yard field goal. On Cleveland's first drive of the third quarter, Cundiff scored on a 37-yarder, followed by 47- and 29-yard kicks to increase the margin by 13 points. In the fourth quarter, Fales would be intercepted by <a href="Robert%20Nelson%20%28American%20football%29">Robert Nelson</a>. The Browns scored the final score of the game with <a href="Isaiah%20Crowell">Isaiah Crowell</a>'s 48-yard field goal, making the final score 33–13.
Regular season.
Buildup.
Michael C. Wright and Jeff Dickerson of <a href="ESPN">ESPN</a> made predictions regarding how the season goes for the Bears, believing the team will go 10–6 and 11–5, respectively.
John McMullen of "<a href="The%20Miami%20Herald">The Miami Herald</a>" assigned grades for each position group but the quarterbacks entering the season, the highest being a B+ for the wide receivers and offensive line, while the lowest being a C+ for the linebackers and special teams. McMullen stated <a href="Jay%20Cutler">Jay Cutler</a>'s extension was "a prudent move", and while he "might not be in the <a href="Peyton%20Manning">Manning</a>–<a href="Tom%20Brady">Brady</a>–<a href="Aaron%20Rodgers">Rodgers</a> class but is on the tier below". Regarding the running backs, McMullen wrote that while <a href="Matt%20Forte">Matt Forte</a> is one of the top running backs, there is not an impressive depth behind him, while the wide receiving corps may be "the best in the business", but <a href="Marquess%20Wilson">Marquess Wilson</a>'s injury led to a lack of depth; behind tight end <a href="Martellus%20Bennett">Martellus Bennett</a>, Zach Miller's injury led to <a href="Dante%20Rosario">Dante Rosario</a> and <a href="Matthew%20Mulligan">Matthew Mulligan</a> serving as backups, the former having "decent hands but just average speed", while the latter having "bounced around". The offensive line was considered the "most improved in 2013", with all five starters returning, while the defensive line has been refurbished with <a href="Jared%20Allen">Jared Allen</a> and <a href="Lamarr%20Houston">Lamarr Houston</a>'s signings. For the linebackers, <a href="Lance%20Briggs">Lance Briggs</a> and <a href="D.%20J.%20Williams%20%28linebacker%29">D. J. Williams</a> would return as starters, while <a href="Shea%20McClellin">Shea McClellin</a>, who had converted to linebacker, being written by McMullen as a move that "has a chance if defensive coordinator <a href="Mel%20Tucker">Mel Tucker</a> lets McClellin go straight ahead as a disruptor and not expect the former <a href="Boise%20State%20Broncos%20football">Boise State</a> star to play in space".
The Bears did not have <a href="National%20Football%20League%20team%20captains">team captains</a> for 2014, breaking a seven-year trend. Head coach Marc Trestman stated he intended to select captains weekly.
Schedule.
The schedule was announced on April 23. ESPN ranked the Bears' schedule as the 15th strongest in the league, with opponents having a combined winning percentage of .496. The Bears will open the season with six away games from weeks 2–10, due to three conflicting events in the Chicago area: week 2 is unavailable due to a <a href="NASCAR">NASCAR</a> race and <a href="Professional%20Golfers%20Association%20of%20America">PGA</a> golf tournament, week 6 due to the <a href="Chicago%20Marathon">Chicago Marathon</a> utilizing Soldier Field as a start/finish line, and week 9 due to a <a href="rugby%20union">rugby union</a> game at Soldier Field on Saturday night. To resolve the situation regarding week 9, league schedulers created a bye week for the Bears. The Bears will also play five <a href="prime%20time">prime time</a> games, the most allowed by the league scheduling, and a Thanksgiving Day game during the season. In December, the Bears had three consecutive home games, the first since <a href="2008%20Chicago%20Bears%20season">2008</a> and the second since <a href="1963%20Chicago%20Bears%20season">1963</a>. Although CBS, which airs <a href="American%20Football%20Conference">AFC</a> games against the Lions on Thanksgiving, held the rights to the game for 2014, the league's new "crossflexing" policy, which allows CBS and Fox to switch seven games, permitted the Bears to play Detroit.
Game summaries.
Week 1: vs. Buffalo Bills.
The Bears opened the season at home against the <a href="2014%20Buffalo%20Bills%20season">Buffalo Bills</a>, who had a record of 6–10 in <a href="2013%20Buffalo%20Bills%20season">2013</a>. Entering the game, the Bears were 54–35–5 in season openers, the most wins of any team, and they had not lost an opening game since 2009, the most in the NFC and second-most in the NFL behind the <a href="New%20England%20Patriots">New England Patriots</a>. The Bears were 7–4 against the Bills, with their last meeting being a 22–19 victory in Toronto in <a href="2010%20Chicago%20Bears%20season">2010</a>, while winning 40–7 in the last game between the two at <a href="Soldier%20Field">Soldier Field</a>; the Bears had won all five meetings between the two in Chicago. When comparing the two teams in 2013 statistically, the Bears had the advantage in three offensive categories (points scored, total offense, and passing offense), while the Bills had the second-best rushing offense, compared to the Bears' 16th-ranked rushing game. On defense, the Bears were outmatched in all three categories (total defense, rushing defense, and passing defense), but are one spot higher than Buffalo in turnover ratio (+5 to +3). <a href="Scout.com">Scout.com</a>'s Jeremy Stoltz writes that one of the players the Bears must contain is the defensive tackle duo of <a href="Mario%20Williams">Mario Williams</a> and <a href="Marcell%20Dareus">Marcell Dareus</a>, who had a combined 139 total tackles, 18.0 sacks and two forced fumbles during 2013. While the Bears' offensive line boasted the fourth-least sacks, none of the five starters played in the preseason. As a result, to combat the rush, the Bears need <a href="Jay%20Cutler">Jay Cutler</a> to release the ball quickly. For the Bears' defense, Stoltz stated all the Bears needed to do was stop Buffalo's running backs <a href="Fred%20Jackson%20%28running%20back%29">Fred Jackson</a> and <a href="C.%20J.%20Spiller">C. J. Spiller</a>, as the Bills had the second-best rushing attack in the league. The Bears were favored to win by seven points, the third-largest spread of the week. <a href="Matt%20Fort%C3%A9">Matt Forté</a>, <a href="Charles%20Tillman">Charles Tillman</a>, and <a href="Robbie%20Gould">Robbie Gould</a> were the captains for the game. <a href="David%20Fales">David Fales</a>, <a href="Kelvin%20Hayden">Kelvin Hayden</a>, <a href="Tony%20Fiammetta">Tony Fiammetta</a>, <a href="Khaseem%20Greene">Khaseem Greene</a>, <a href="Charles%20Leno%20Jr.">Charles Leno Jr.</a>, <a href="David%20Bass%20%28American%20football%29">David Bass</a> and <a href="Cornelius%20Washington">Cornelius Washington</a> were inactive for the game.
The Bears won the coin toss, and elected to kick. After Buffalo punted, Chicago scored on Cutler's 12-yard touchdown pass to <a href="Martellus%20Bennett">Martellus Bennett</a>, which the Bills retaliated with <a href="E.%20J.%20Manuel">E. J. Manuel</a>'s two-yard touchdown run. On the Bears' first drive of the second quarter, <a href="Brandon%20Marshall">Brandon Marshall</a> fumbled, with linebacker <a href="Preston%20Brown%20%28linebacker%29">Preston Brown</a> recovering; the Bills would score on <a href="Dan%20Carpenter">Dan Carpenter</a>'s 50-yard field goal. Afterwards, Cutler was intercepted by former Bear <a href="Corey%20Graham">Corey Graham</a> after Bennett did not "turn to look for the ball in time", with the Bills again capitalizing on the takeaway, with Manuel's seven-yard touchdown pass to Spiller, and the half ended with Buffalo leading 17–7. On the Bears' first possession of the third quarter, Gould kicked a five-yard field goal, and on the Bills' first drive of the half, <a href="Chris%20Conte">Chris Conte</a> read a pass intended for <a href="Marquise%20Goodwin">Marquise Goodwin</a>, stepping in front of the pass to intercept the ball. On Chicago's ensuing drive, the offense rallied to tie the score on Cutler's 11-yard touchdown pass to Marshall. In the fourth quarter, the Bears drove from their own six-yard line to reach the Buffalo 34, but Cutler's forced pass intended for Bennett was intercepted by <a href="Kyle%20Williams%20%28defensive%20tackle%29">Kyle Williams</a>; Carpenter would kick a 33-yard field goal, which the Bears responded with Gould's 37-yarder. The Bills would <a href="quarterback%20kneel">kneel</a> to end regulation with a 20–20 score. After the Bears went three-and-out, the Bills started on their own 22-yard line, but drove to the Bears' 39. On the next play, Jackson found a hole in the line of scrimmage, getting past <a href="Lance%20Briggs">Lance Briggs</a>. Conte reached Jackson at the 20-yard line, but was <a href="stiff-arm%20fend">stiff-armed</a>; Conte attempted to tackle again, but was knocked down, with Jackson being pushed out of bounds at the one-yard line. Two plays later, Carpenter kicked the game-winning 27-yard field goal.
Four of the Bears' offensive starters suffered injuries during the game: <a href="Roberto%20Garza">Roberto Garza</a> (right ankle) and <a href="Matt%20Slauson">Matt Slauson</a> (left ankle) did not play after the first half, <a href="Alshon%20Jeffery">Alshon Jeffery</a> (hamstring) departed in the third quarter, while Marshall (right ankle) was hurt after being tackled. Conte received scrutiny after the game for failing to tackle Jackson, but defended himself by saying, "It was a play where it's the end of the game – I've got to get the ball out or something. If I hit him, it's a field goal no matter what, so I've got to try and get the ball out. It's a desperation play where I've got to try and punch the ball or something."
Week 2: at San Francisco 49ers.
In the previous meeting between Chicago and <a href="2014%20San%20Francisco%2049ers%20season">San Francisco</a> at <a href="Candlestick%20Park">Candlestick Park</a> in <a href="2012%20Chicago%20Bears%20season">2012</a>, the 49ers won 32–7. Entering the game, the 49ers led the all-time series 32–29–1; while the Bears had won five of the last eight meetings between the two since <a href="2001%20Chicago%20Bears%20season">2001</a>, they had lost all eight road games against the 49ers since <a href="1985%20Chicago%20Bears%20season">1985</a>. Comparing the two teams' week one rankings, the Bears had more total and passing yards than the 49ers, 427–319 and 341–192, respectively, while the 49ers had more rushing yards (127–86). Defensively, the 49ers allowed more yards (382–360) and allowed two more sacks than the Bears in week one. Writing for <a href="WBBM-TV">WBBM-TV</a>, Bears radio play-by-play commentator <a href="Jeff%20Joniak">Jeff Joniak</a> stated the Bears' offense had a chance to utilize their running backs, as the 49ers had allowed the <a href="Dallas%20Cowboys">Dallas Cowboys</a> to record 100 rushing yards in week one, the first time in 18 games, and with linebackers <a href="NaVorro%20Bowman">NaVorro Bowman</a> and <a href="Aldon%20Smith">Aldon Smith</a> inactive, the Bears had the chance to attack on the ground. For the Bears' passing game, recording short passes was important, while stating playing against the 49ers' defense "requires patience", with <a href="Vic%20Fangio">Vic Fangio</a> utilizing <a href="zone%20defense">zone defense</a> blitzes. Additionally, Jay Cutler had struggled against the 49ers during his career, being 0–2, with one touchdown, six interceptions, and a 59.2 passer rating. On defense, the Bears had to contain <a href="Colin%20Kaepernick">Colin Kaepernick</a>, who had thrown for two touchdowns the previous week and recorded his fourth-best passer rating (125.5), and in his first career start, had guided the 49ers to the victory over the Bears in 2012. The Bears also faced a challenge in 49ers' running backs <a href="Frank%20Gore">Frank Gore</a> and rookie <a href="Carlos%20Hyde">Carlos Hyde</a>, the former having become the 29th player to record 10,000 career rushing yards the previous week, and the latter averaged 7.1 yards and scored a touchdown. Against San Francisco's receivers, while <a href="Anquan%20Boldin">Anquan Boldin</a> and <a href="Michael%20Crabtree">Michael Crabtree</a> were not fast, their physicality allows them to make blocks and "bully defensive backs". The 49ers were favorites to win, with every <a href="ESPN">ESPN</a> analyst but former Bears head coach <a href="Mike%20Ditka">Mike Ditka</a> to predict a 49ers victory. <a href="Jermon%20Bushrod">Jermon Bushrod</a>, <a href="Lamarr%20Houston">Lamarr Houston</a>, and <a href="Sherrick%20McManis">Sherrick McManis</a> served as team captains. For the game, <a href="Josh%20Morgan">Josh Morgan</a>, Khaseem Greene, Roberto Garza, Matt Slauson, Charles Leno Jr., David Bass, and Cornelius Washington were scratched.
The 49ers won the coin toss, and decided to kick. On the Bears' first drive, <a href="Pat%20O%27Donnell">Pat O'Donnell</a>'s punt was blocked by <a href="Aaron%20Lynch%20%28American%20football%29">Aaron Lynch</a>, and the 49ers scored on Kaepernick's three-yard touchdown pass to Crabtree, the first score in Levi's Stadium history after the play stood via review. On the 49ers' next drive, Kaepernick was intercepted by Charles Tillman, but the pick was overturned; <a href="Phil%20Dawson">Phil Dawson</a> would kick a 27-yard field goal, the final score of the first quarter. On San Francisco's second drive of the second quarter, Kaepernick's pass for Boldin would be intercepted by a diving Chris Conte, though the Bears failed to take advantage, being forced to punt. Gore would then score on a 54-yard run, which was nullified by a holding call on Boldin, and two plays later, Kaepernick was stripped by <a href="Jared%20Allen">Jared Allen</a>, and the ball was recovered by <a href="Danny%20McCray">Danny McCray</a>, but the Bears would again be forced to punt. The 49ers extended the lead by ten points on Gore's eight-yard touchdown run, but the Bears managed to score for the first time in the half on Cutler's 17-yard touchdown pass to Brandon Marshall, who caught the pass with one hand. In the second half, the 49ers scored on Dawson's 24-yard kick, culminating a drive that took 9:04. On the Bears' next drive, Cutler threw a five-yard touchdown pass to Marshall, narrowing the score to 20–14. On the first play of San Francisco's next drive, Kaepernick's pass for Crabtree was pulled away by <a href="Kyle%20Fuller">Kyle Fuller</a>, with the Bears scoring on the first play with Cutler's three-yard touchdown to Martellus Bennett to give the Bears the 21–20 lead. Kaepernick was intercepted again by Fuller on the next drive after Fuller reached his pass intended for <a href="Derek%20Carrier">Derek Carrier</a>, the Bears converting the pick into a Cutler three-yard touchdown to Marshall, increasing the lead by eight. On San Francisco's final drive, the offense reached Chicago's 17-yard line, but on 4th down, Kaepernick's pass to Crabtree fell incomplete, and Cutler kneeled twice to end the game.
The game featured 26 penalties, 10 by the Bears for 58 yards, and 16 by the 49ers for 118 yards. Late in the second quarter, Cutler, who had completed only 8 of 18 passes for 38 yards, was hit by <a href="Quinton%20Dial">Quinton Dial</a>, and after the hit, Cutler completed 15 of 16 passes for 138 yards and four touchdowns. Fuller became the first rookie in Bears history to record two interceptions in a game since <a href="Chris%20Harris%20%28safety%29">Chris Harris</a> against the <a href="Green%20Bay%20Packers">Green Bay Packers</a> in <a href="2005%20Chicago%20Bears%20season">2005</a>.
Week 3: at New York Jets.
The Bears traveled to <a href="East%20Rutherford%2C%20New%20Jersey">East Rutherford, New Jersey</a> to play the <a href="2014%20New%20York%20Jets%20season">New York Jets</a> on "<a href="Monday%20Night%20Football">Monday Night Football</a>", the Bears having won the last three meeting between the two since 2001, the last being a 38–34 win in <a href="2010%20Chicago%20Bears%20season">2010</a>, and the Bears led the all-time series 7–3. When comparing the two teams, Brad Gagnon of <a href="CBSSports.com">CBSSports.com</a> stated they are "complete opposites", with <a href="Marc%20Trestman">Marc Trestman</a> being a pass-first coach, while <a href="Rex%20Ryan">Rex Ryan</a> prefers running first; as a result, while the Bears were ranked higher in passer rating (9th to 25th) and QB rating against (4th to 26th), the Jets had the advantage in yards per carry (5th to 23rd) and yards per carry against (3rd to 28th). In the running game, Gagnon writes the Bears' 23rd-ranked rushing offense would have trouble against the third-ranked Jets run defense, which had allowed only 2.8 yards per carry. He adds that as a result, the Bears would be forced to throw – 71 percent of Chicago's offensive plays had been passing, the most in the league, which Gagnon states is not a "good thing", as the five teams with the highest passing percentage in the NFL in 2013 had losing records. Additionally, the passing attack would have to defend against the rush, with the Jets blitzing 75 percent of the time; New York had recorded 47 sacks since week one of 2013, tied for the 10th most in the league, while <a href="Pro%20Football%20Focus">Pro Football Focus</a> ranked <a href="Muhammad%20Wilkerson">Muhammad Wilkerson</a> and <a href="Sheldon%20Richardson">Sheldon Richardson</a> as the top 12 pass-rushing <a href="3%E2%80%934%20defense">3–4 defensive</a> ends in the NFL, with <a href="Quinton%20Coples">Quinton Coples</a> having the most QB pressures of a 3–4 OLB with ten. However, Jay Cutler had completed 67 percent of passes under pressure, the second-most in the NFL. the Bears led the league in completions of four yards or more on first down with 21, and despite injuries to Brandon Marshall and Alshon Jeffery, the passing game could have a chance against a secondary that struggled in the previous week against the Packers. Matt Forte would also be a viable passing option, but the Jets had the fifth-fewest receiving yards by an RB allowed with 28.5 On defense, the Bears would have to stop the Jets' rushing game, which led the league with 358 total rushing yards, while tying for third in the NFL with 33 runs of four yards or more, and averaged 5.54 yards on first down. <a href="Chris%20Ivory">Chris Ivory</a> also had the highest rushing average with 6.3 yards, while the Jets averaged 5 yards offensively, and the Bears were allowing 5.3 yards per carry, while allowing a total of 320 yards and four touchdowns on 60 carries. On special teams, the Bears had promoted <a href="Rashad%20Ross">Rashad Ross</a>, who averaged 32 return yards with the <a href="Washington%20Redskins">Washington Redskins</a> in the preseason, from the practice squad, which appeared to be an improvement over <a href="Senorise%20Perry">Senorise Perry</a>, who had returned only two of eleven kickoffs in the first two games of the season. The betting line for the game was New York by -2.5. The Bears' captains were Cutler, Lance Briggs, and <a href="Danny%20McCray">Danny McCray</a>, while Sherrick McManis, <a href="Shea%20McClellin">Shea McClellin</a>, Roberto Garza, Matt Slauson, Charles Leno Jr., and <a href="Trevor%20Scott">Trevor Scott</a> were not active.
The Bears won the coin toss, and deferred until the second half. On the second play of the Jets' first drive, Smith's fake <a href="screen%20pass">screen pass</a> was intercepted by <a href="Ryan%20Mundy">Ryan Mundy</a>, scoring on a 45-yard return. After the Jets punted, the Bears also were forced to punt, but <a href="Jalen%20Saunders">Jalen Saunders</a> muffed the punt, which was recovered by <a href="Ahmad%20Dixon">Ahmad Dixon</a>. Four plays later, Jay Cutler threw a seven-yard touchdown pass to Martellus Bennett, with New York scoring the final points of the first quarter via <a href="Nick%20Folk">Nick Folk</a>'s 43-yard field goal. Both teams exchanged field goals on their first drives of the second quarter. On the Jets' next drive, Smith connected with <a href="Jeremy%20Kerley">Jeremy Kerley</a> on a 19-yard pass to make the score 17–13. On the Bears' following possession, Cutler was stripped by <a href="David%20Harris%20%28American%20football%29">David Harris</a>, with <a href="Demario%20Davis">Demario Davis</a> scoring on the return. However, the officials had believed Cutler was downed prior to losing the ball, and while a challenge ruled the play as a fumble, the touchdown was not recorded. Despite the takeaway, the Jets would be forced to punt. The half would end with no additional scoring. On Chicago's first drive of the second half, Cutler threw a 13-yard touchdown pass to Bennett. After both teams traded punts, Smith and the Jets reached the Bears' 18-yard line, but was his pass intended for <a href="David%20Nelson%20%28wide%20receiver%29">David Nelson</a> was intercepted by Kyle Fuller in the endzone. The Jets would later kick a 22-yard field goal. In the final quarter, Folk kicked a 42-yarder, with Robbie Gould kicking one of 45 yards on the next drive, the score becoming 27–19. On New York's final drive of the game, the offense reached the Bears' nine-yard line, but on 4th and 5, Smith's pass for Kerley was defended by rookie <a href="Brock%20Vereen">Brock Vereen</a>, and despite catching the ball, Kerley was out of bounds. The Bears kneeled three times to end the game.
The game marked the first time since week 16 of <a href="2012%20Chicago%20Bears%20season">2012</a> against the <a href="Arizona%20Cardinals">Arizona Cardinals</a> that the Bears allowed fewer than 20 points in a game. Fuller, who was making his first career start, became the first NFL player in the last 20 years to record three interceptions and two forced fumbles in the first three games.
Week 4: vs. Green Bay Packers.
For week four, the Bears donned their 1940s throwbacks when they hosted the 1–2 <a href="2014%20Green%20Bay%20Packers%20season">Packers</a>, the Bears having led the <a href="Bears-Packers%20rivalry">all-time series</a> 93–89–2, but the Packers had won 9 of the previous 11 games. On offense, the Bears' worst-ranked rushing game (64 yards per game) had a chance to produce against the Packers, who were ranked 30th by allowing 156 yards per game, while opponents had run a league-most 37.3 times per game while scoring an also league-high five rushing touchdowns. Also, Matt Forte had recorded 336 yards and four touchdowns against the Packers in his last two games. The offense also was challenged by the pass defense, with defenders <a href="Sam%20Shields">Sam Shields</a> and <a href="Tramon%20Williams">Tramon Williams</a>, who were stingy in <a href="man-to-man%20defense">man coverage</a>. For the Bears' defense, the Packers had also struggled on the run, ranking 26th in the league with a 78-yard rushing average and the longest run being of 17 yards, while having averaged only 3.63 yards per carry. Additionally, Green Bay was ranked 28th in the league in yards. However, the team faced the Packers' passing attack, which featured the receiving duo of <a href="Jordy%20Nelson">Jordy Nelson</a> and <a href="Randall%20Cobb%20%28American%20football%29">Randall Cobb</a>. The former led the league in targets (37) and first downs (16), while ranking second in receiving yards (351), while the Bears had struggled with covering <a href="slant%20%28route%29">slant</a> and dig routes, both of which Nelson excelled at. The latter had three touchdowns in 2014, but was used primarily for <a href="hitch%20%28route%29">hitch</a> and stick routes. The Packers were two-point favorites. Sherrick McManis, Shea McClellin, Roberto Garza, Matt Slauson, Jared Allen, Charles Leno Jr., and <a href="Jeremiah%20Ratliff">Jeremiah Ratliff</a> were inactive. <a href="Kyle%20Long">Kyle Long</a>, Alshon Jeffery, and Ryan Mundy served as team captains for the game, while the honorary captains were <a href="Dick%20Butkus">Dick Butkus</a> and <a href="Kurt%20Becker">Kurt Becker</a>.
The Packers won the coin toss, and decided to kick. On the first drive, the Bears scored on Jay Cutler's six-yard touchdown pass to Brandon Marshall, which the Packers responded with <a href="Eddie%20Lacy">Eddie Lacy</a>'s two-yard touchdown run. During Chicago's next drive, on 4th and 1, Cutler fumbled the snap, and upon picking up the ball, recorded a 16-yard run on an accidental <a href="fumblerooski">fumblerooski</a>. The drive continued into the second quarter, ended with Robbie Gould kicking a 23-yard field goal. The two teams exchanged touchdowns on the final three plays: <a href="Aaron%20Rodgers">Aaron Rodgers</a>' three-yard pass to Nelson, Cutler's eight-yard pass to Jeffery, and Rodgers' 22-yard pass to Cobb. The Bears reached the Packers' nine-yard line by the final play of the first half; on the play, Cutler's pass for Bennett was ruled short of a touchdown. Week 11: vs. Minnesota Vikings.
Chicago hosted the 4–5 Vikings in week eleven, the Vikings leading the <a href="Bears-Vikings%20rivalry">all-time rivalry</a> 53–51–4, though the Bears had won six consecutive games at Soldier Field between the two teams, dating back to <a href="2007%20Chicago%20Bears%20season">2007</a>. Jeff Joniak stated the Bears must "play smart"; for instance, on offense, the Bears would have to watch for pressure from a blitz-happy <a href="Mike%20Zimmer">Mike Zimmer</a>-led defense, which ranked third in the league in sacks with 30, 20 of which were in their last four games, and was also ranked third in the NFL in hurries with 60, and forced offenses to commit a league-leading 13 holding penalties. The pass rush would try to attack Jay Cutler, who was tied for the most turnovers with 15, and was sacked 23 times. The Bears won the toss, and elected to defer. On their opening drive, the Vikings scored on <a href="Blair%20Walsh">Blair Walsh</a>'s 50-yard field goal. During the Bears' next drive, a play was whistled dead because Minnesota wanted to challenge whether a previous play was a fumble, and when Cutler voiced his complaints to the referees, he was penalized 15 yards for unsportsmanlike conduct; the ruling eventually stood, costing the Vikings their first timeout. Cutler broke the team record for the most completions with 370, along with career highs in completion percentage (66 percent) and passing touchdowns (28). Despite these milestones, he tied the <a href="2014%20San%20Diego%20Chargers%20season">San Diego Chargers</a>' <a href="Philip%20Rivers">Philip Rivers</a> for the most interceptions in the league with 18, while his 24 total turnovers also led the NFL. The offense also regressed from being the second-ranked scoring unit in the NFL in 2013 with 445 points to just 319 in 2014, while the team failed to score at least 30 points in a game for the first time since <a href="2004%20Chicago%20Bears%20season">2004</a>. The Bears also featured the heaviest passing attack in 2014 as they threw on 63.1 percent of their plays.
On defense, the Bears' adjusted line yards defense, which "measures a defense's control of the line of scrimmage", ranked 30th in the league, a two-spot improvement from 2013. In runs toward the offensive linemen, the team ranked 29th or worse in runs marked left tackle, middle/guard and right tackle. The 30th-ranked defense allowed 381.5 yards per game and a league-most 28.6 points per game.
The struggles were compounded by tensions in the locker room and the staff's difficulties in managing the situation; after losing to Miami, reports surfaced of the team arguing with one another. In December, offensive coordinator <a href="Aaron%20Kromer">Aaron Kromer</a> anonymously criticized Cutler before apologizing; Trestman's actions surrounding the matter drew concern from players, with reports claiming Kromer received "basically a slap on the wrist" as discipline for his comments. The roster was also reportedly "confused and uncomfortable" when Cutler was benched for the week sixteen game against the Lions.
In his 2014 season report card, <a href="ESPN.com">ESPN.com</a>'s Michael C. Wright wrote "Trestman undoubtedly fractured the relationship with the quarterback, but the move called into question general manager <a href="Phil%20Emery%20%28American%20football%29">Phil Emery</a>'s skills as a personnel evaluator." After Trestman's firing, an anonymous player revealed in a 2015 interview with <a href="Bleacher%20Report">Bleacher Report</a> writer <a href="Mike%20Freeman%20%28columnist%29">Mike Freeman</a> that Jeremiah Ratliff was named a team captain days after Ratliff pushed an assistant coach and damaged a practice clock; although Trestman defended the decision, the player explained it created discord among his teammates.
Trestman and Emery were fired on December 29. Coordinators Kromer and <a href="Mel%20Tucker">Mel Tucker</a> were not retained by new head coach <a href="John%20Fox%20%28American%20football%29">John Fox</a>.
Awards and records.
Awards.
On December 23, Kyle Long was named to the <a href="2014%20Pro%20Bowl">2014 Pro Bowl</a>, the only Bear invited. This was his second consecutive <a href="Pro%20Bowl">Pro Bowl</a> invitation, making him the first Bear since <a href="Devin%20Hester">Devin Hester</a> to make the all-star game in his first two seasons, and the tenth in Bears history. On January 2, 2015, Long was named to the <a href="Associated%20Press">Associated Press</a> <a href="All-Pro">All-Pro</a> team, again the lone Bear; he had received five votes, and was named to the second team. In 2014, he didn't allow a single sack.
On January 13, 2015, Pat O'Donnell and Kyle Fuller were named to the <a href="Pro%20Football%20Writers%20Association">Pro Football Writers Association</a>'s All-Rookie Team. On April 7, Matt Slauson was awarded the NFL's <a href="Ed%20Block%20Courage%20Award">Ed Block Courage Award</a>.
